metadata.title: SQLite Database Setup and Querying | by Matt Przybyla | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: SQL querying for your local database - DB Browser for SQLite. A tutorial to set up your database, modify, query to obtain results for data science datasets.

all_paragraphs: Have you ever wanted to set up a local database and query it? If the answer is yes, then continue reading. Whether you want to practice your SQL skills for an upcoming interview, study up on different querying techniques for your current position, or possibly start up your own company and house your test data, DB Browser for SQLite is for you.

Once you have established your database with tables. You can then run queries that would ultimately serve as your dataset for your machine learning model. You can also use this tool for exploratory data analysis, apart from Python and pandas in your Jupyter Notebook. Additionally, you can obtain metrics that can serve as features for your model.
Below, I will discuss DB Browser for SQLite, the setup, and examples, so that by the end of this article, you can be up and running with your own local database.

DB Browser for SQLite [2] is a tool where you can visualize databases and tables that you create, edit, and query. It is open source and used by some to start their SQL journey. While there are several platforms by other companies, this interface is easy to use and set up. Below, I will show how you can set up your first database and its respective tables.

Once you download this tool, you can easily create a new database as seen in the screenshot above. In my experience, I created two test tables named accounts and names that will be used as examples. In order to set up your specific tables, you can extract data from a CSV file. From the same screenshot above, you can click on the Import option and then hit ‘Table from CSV file…’ — you can also choose to work with ‘Database from SQL file…’. Importing a CSV file is easy and takes seconds to load — I recommend this option for your first time in this tool.
Once you import your data into tables, you can then modify the tables to easily change the type of the fields or columns. This section will be in the Database Structure menu. The options are:

In the screenshot above, you will see the fields that you can edit — another phrase for this is ‘Editing table definitions’. The top part (Type) is essentially visualizing what you could also do with SQL code (Schema) on the bottom — easier to most, but both options are available.

Now the exciting part is actually querying those tables you previously created. The next section will visualize and describe how you can use SQL to return results for your exploratory data analysis and data science model datasets.

The gratifying part of this entire process is being able to query using SQL. In the above screenshot, you can see this simple query of selecting all of the fields that are in the accounts table where the amount is greater than 200. Only one row was returned, meaning that only account_id had satisfied this condition. This type of querying is similar to other subtypes of SQL, with some small differences.

Just like in other SQL platforms, you can perform more complex querying such as joins and where clauses. The above screenshot visualizes the selection of three fields: a.account_id, a.name, and n.location. The single letter is an indication of the full name of the respective table — also known as an alias. I then performed a left join on the names table to retrieve results where there was a match on the accounts table. Next, I wanted to only see results where the location was in the countries of the United States (US) or Australia (AUS). Overall, I was able to merge two tables together in order to retrieve the information I wanted by establishing specific conditions.

While these queries were not especially complex, they were included to visually describe the type of querying you can perform using this useful tool. I had a lot of fun setting this tutorial up while providing some useful instructions on common parts of this platform. While I covered some, there are still plenty of other tips and tricks that you can perform. The original reference will have further examples and documentation regarding DB Browser for SQLite.
To conclude, with this tool, you can create a local database, import data, modify tables, and execute queries for your exploratory data analysis or data science model datasets.
I hope you found this article interesting and useful. Thank you for reading!
